qas.question: What year did Black leaders call for this change in language?
What group decided to keep the "African" in their name?
What terms did African Americans use instead?

context: By that time, <a0_0>the majority of black people in the United States were native-born<a0_0/>, so the use of the term "African" became problematic. Though initially a source of pride, many blacks feared that the use of African as an identity <a1_0>would be a hindrance to their fight for full citizenship in the US.<a1_0/> They also felt that it would give ammunition to those who were advocating repatriating black people back to Africa. In <a2_0>1835,<a2_0/> black leaders called upon Black Americans to remove the title of "African" from their institutions and replace it with "Negro" or "Colored American". A few institutions chose to keep their historic names, such as <a3_0>the African Methodist Episcopal Church<a3_0/>. African Americans popularly used the terms <a4_0>"Negro" or "colored"<a4_0/> for themselves until the late 1960s.
